Legal_Issue: Does the Minister have authority under the New Regulations to de-list the 053 Patent, and does the 053 Patent meet eligibility requirements?
Application_Facts: The Minister argued that the 053 Patent did not meet eligibility requirements because it lacked specific claims for NSAID ulcers and included polymorphic forms. However, expert evidence showed the patent implicitly covered NSAID ulcers, and polymorphic claims do not disqualify it.
Decision_Outcome: The 053 Patent meets eligibility requirements and should not have been removed from the Patent Register.
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review application challenging the Minister's decision to de-list the patent
Court_Ruling: Court allowed the application, ordering the reinstatement of the 053 Patent on the Patent Register.
Defendant_Behavior: The Minister de-listed the 053 Patent based on interpretation of eligibility requirements under the New Regulations.
Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over interpretation of New Regulations leading to de-listing of a patent.
Credibility_Assessment: Expert evidence was considered credible in showing implicit coverage of NSAID ulcers.
Evidence_Used: Expert evidence regarding patent coverage and polymorphic forms
Application_Basis: Interpretation of regulatory provisions regarding patent eligibility
Evidence_Assessed: Expert testimony on patent scope and technical claims
Relief_Sought: Reinstatement of the 053 Patent on the Patent Register
Outcome: Court allowed the application and ordered reinstatement.
Cause_Description: Dispute over interpretation of New Regulations leading to de-listing of a patent.
Evidence_Handling: Expert evidence was admitted and found persuasive.
Legal_Provision_Violated: None found; the Minister's interpretation was deemed incorrect.
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence assessed as sufficient to establish implicit coverage of NSAID ulcers and validity of polymorphic claims
Decision_Rationale: The 053 Patent meets eligibility requirements under the correct interpretation of the regulations.
